seneca-api.name: add
seneca-api.function: Add a new action to the Seneca instance
seneca-api.usedwhen: The action is triggered when an object matching the pattern is submitted to Seneca using the act method

seneca-api.name: export
seneca-api.function: Returns a reference to a named object.
seneca-api.usedwhen: These are provided by some plugins so that you can integrate into other systems (for example, providing a middleware function for express).

seneca-api.name: make
seneca-api.function: Create an instance of a data entity
seneca-api.usedwhen: The entity-canon defines the kind of entity to create ('product', 'sys/user', ...), and the properties (optional) define the values of some of the entity fields.

seneca-api.name: pin
seneca-api.function: api_pin: Creates a convenience object that can call actions directly using method calls.
seneca-api.usedwhen: makes it less verbose to make method calls

seneca-api.name: act
seneca-api.function: api_act: Invoke an action using an object.
seneca-api.usedwhen: The action pattern that matches the object in the most specific manner will be invoked.

seneca-api.name: close
seneca-api.function: Calls the close:name action on all plugins that have registered this action.
seneca-api.usedwhen: You can use this to close database connections after tests complete to ensure the process ends.

seneca-api.name: ready
seneca-api.function: api_ready: Provide a callback to be executed once all the plugins registered up this point are initialized
seneca-api.usedwhen: To wait for database connections to establish

seneca-api.name: use
seneca-api.usedwhen: Where a plugin usually add some actions to the Seneca instance

seneca-api.name: log.level
seneca-api.function: Create a log entry using the Seneca logging system.
seneca-api.usedwhen: Use this inside plugins as it handles all the context information (time, which plugin, etc) for you. Levels are debug, info, warn, error, fatal.

stackmates.name: drive.google.com
stackmates.why: Free and very useful. Allow people to use excel to communicate ideas which is what business is used to

stackmates.name: nodejs.org
stackmates.why: node will become the vital link between business internals and the outside world (see hapijs story) it also enables real-time web applications
stackmates.productivity: yes, number one reason why node has had such high adoption with large organisations is because small experiments ended up becoming too compelling due to speed at which solutions can be developed
stackmates.flexibility: Code javascript so you can use same skill on front and backend development
stackmates.problems: Still quite new so not as well known as Rails or as much high quality education that is affordably available. The events model takes a bit of getting used to.

stackmates.name: npmjs.org
stackmates.job: provide a central repo of modules that can be readily searched and reliably accessed to retrieve modules
stackmates.problems: Finding the right module. You need a strong set of heuristics to know what to look for which is hard for beginers
stackmates.backers: the node ecosytem largely runs on npm

stackmates.name: gulpjs.com
stackmates.why: it is fast and becoming ubiquitous, used by google
stackmates.productivity: it was much faster than grunt. Also uses streams which is better fit with node
stackmates.problems: Can be hard to get started. It in a pain to have to continually update build systems for each project you create, but again that is why StackMates exists

stackmates.name: browserify.org
stackmates.why: ESSENTIAL - Substack and browserify is the inspiration for StackMates because browserify is awesome and the very best engineers have voted for it with their commitment
stackmates.productivity: you write clean modular small bits of code. This means that it easy to follow what is happening and to replace. There is 1000s of reusable modules
stackmates.performance: Much faster to bring everything together than using other systems
stackmates.flexibility: With knowledge of the browserify module systems you can build anything
stackmates.adoption: Browserify opens up a door to completely rethink the border between front and backend. The full potential of browserify is yet to be realised.
stackmates.problems: Because there are so many modules it takes a lot of effort to know the ecoystem. But that is exactly the reason why StackMates exists

stackmates.name: rework & suit.css
stackmates.why: CSS is underated for importance of good architecture and the effect on time / cost. Poorly thought out CSS strategies waste lots of money and make bringing new features to make slower. Suit.CSS provides a system to help prevent that. With REWORK it is also extremely fast to build and is aligned with future specifications for core CSS so won't have to relearn when those standards are adopted
stackmates.productivity: Initally slower as you need to think harder about what you are doing. But as projects grow and become more complex and standards evolve this is where Suit.css has an enormous payback
stackmates.performance: lightning fast, much faster than sass.
stackmates.flexibility: It is modular so you can build the CSS system as you like. It is future standard compliant so no need to rewrite CSS if want be standards compliant in future
stackmates.adoption: If a library of patterns were established with good semantics development of sites and the ability to experiment with UX will sky rocket. See StackMates link to see more
stackmates.problems: Because you can build (was) a bit challenging to get started with rework. But again that is why StackMates exists

stackmates.name: http://sass-lang.com/
stackmates.why:
For smaller jobs until a full Suit.CSS based UX library is built up it  worth using something that exists such as foundation. 

Used by ionic and many other frameworks.

stackmates.name: ionicframework.com
stackmates.why: Best mobile - native bridge using web tech also a well run community
stackmates.productivity: Ionic and angular can leverage same code base to scale solutions in parallel

stackmates.name: angularjs.com
stackmates.why: By google, popular, strong emphasis on testing tools largely influenced by selection of Ionic for mobile and economies of code reuse
stackmates.problems: What is the direction of angular 2.0? Is it going to be browserify friendly?

stackmates.name: mercury
stackmates.why: Uses Functional Reactive Programming. A concept the I don't fully comprehend but can see value of
stackmates.productivity: After initial learning curve should in theory enable greater productivity and concepts would "flow"

stackmates.name: metalsmith.io
stackmates.job: Build static sites, landing pages, ebooks, marketing collatoral, adverts
stackmates.why: Flexibilty powered by node so fast

stackmates.name: handlebarsjs.com
stackmates.job: Render html templates for metalsmith but could also work with Hapijs or Meteor
stackmates.why: UTILITY - Handlebars is used in a number of high profile projects to offers rich learning example and reuse of skllls mastered
stackmates.productivity: easy to find help for patterns
stackmates.performance: Seems handlebars will soon be supeceded
stackmates.flexibility: Knoweledge and patterns can be resused with Meteor and emberjs

stackmates.name: hapijs.com
stackmates.job: connection private (internal) to public (external) providing safety and enhanced communication tools
stackmates.why: Hapi is very well thought out to provide the interface between public and private

stackmates.name: senecajs.com
stackmates.why: Can start writing app in traditional sence and then "break out" as MSA. One of the most public projects for teaching how, with already a big ecossytem of plugins to leverage

stackmates.name: mongodb.com
stackmates.why: This could be anything for data layer. But mongo is pretty well known

stackmates.name: cloud.google.com
stackmates.why: Google is the best at this stuff

stackmates.name: github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes
stackmates.why: Google is the best at this stuff. Bullet proof deploys, scalabilty, portability (no lock in)

stackmates.name: github.com/nearform/nscale
stackmates.why: Behind seneca / know the pain of running MSA solutions

externalProvoke.haikuThought: What tech stack will run the business models of the future?
externalProvoke.haikuAction: What is the cost of inertia?
externalProvoke.excerpt: MOVING FORWARD The best way to create software solutions is about using 1000s of tiny modules as kind of lego blocks to make big solutions.
externalProvoke.html:
MOVING FORWARD The best way to create software solutions is about using 1000s of tiny modules as kind of lego blocks to make big solutions.

Why not think of your tech stack like a portfolio stocks where developers and companies share the StackMates they use to build a global index that provides insights into trends for what concepts are gaining momentum for the purposes of driving education and recruitment and staying on top on innovation?

Digital footprint

Now consider for a moment The Operating Model That Is Eating The World then ask yourself

What is the typical digital footprint for a business that desires to evolve at the speed of the web?

See this mind map for more analysis, but for the purposes of evaluating a concrete example of an aspiring startup the following is a breakdown of the Ionicframework project that is publicly available.

Marketing

  • home
  • learn
  • blog
  • presentation

Apps

Mobile
  • Android
  • IOS
  • Other
Tablet
  • Web
  • Native
Desktop
  • Consumer facing
  • Internal line of business

Other Solutions

  • Forum
  • Ecommerce

Observations

A conservative count of github projects shows 7 build, CSS and JS configs to maintains. If you factor in the need for specific marketing campaign pages or facebook pages this number could easily grow.

  • The blog is not a subdomain but this would be typical
  • The Ionic brand is consistent in all they communicate
  • Multiple build systems and CSS theme configurations
  • Heavy javascript and Node bias but also use Ruby and Rails for their soluton stack
  • There is no ionicframework mobile app but this would be a typical requirement
  • It is unclear whether a desktop solution exists to help run their business

Pain points

  • How much of this code is common but is copied?
  • How much effort goes into updating build systems for each project?
  • How much effort to align consistent branding?
  • How are best UX Patterns maintained across all properties?
  • Why not use JS solutions for forum or ecommerce?
Can the energy used to teach others be better used for a greater good?

externalProvoke.haikuAction: Don't paint yourself into a corner
externalProvoke.excerpt: Create multiple client sites or apps from a StackMates Starter to begin evolving your digital footprint from a common base using a system designed to maximise code reuse with ...
externalProvoke.html:
Create multiple client sites or apps from a StackMates Starter to begin evolving your digital footprint from a common base using a system designed to maximise code reuse with

  • Ability to seperate client and backend work
  • A common build system for all your client projects (less maintenance)
  • Choice of Rework or SASS
  • Choice of UX Patterns with Handlebars and Angular
  • Static sites for marketing with Metalsmith
  • CORS Authentication
  • Build web and mobile apps that share angular logic
  • Roll your apps with Browserify
  • Easily common CSS style rules across all digital properties
  • Hapijs API
  • Seneca Micro-service
  • Vagrant + Docker development environment

All in around 20 mins plus the time to have a coffee while npm installs modules. To start building with your own stack follow these instructions

What are StackMates

StackMates are represented by a collection of configuration files that pull together fullstack solutions from micro components.

The creation of StackMates was directly influenced by watching the following talks by Substack and Fred George with the intent to create a better way to share knowledge of how micro components can be creatively combined to solve large problems. A hopeful by-product is to help research scientists solve the real problems we face while in turn providing developers challenges to solve and teach with that have context and positive impact.

  • Client: Tiny Modules by Substack
  • Services: Implementing Microservice Architectures by Fred George

Selection Criteria

Solutions are temporary but good questions are timeless. The main goal of this project is to advance how to interpret the value of different approaches to developing software. See mind map for ideas on selection criteria.

Leadership

  • A strong custodian that lives by their values

Communication

  • Clearly defines job to be done
  • Strong focus on teaching

Innovation

Development
  • Productivity
  • Performance
  • Flexibility
Ecosystem
  • Dyanamic library
  • Developer adoption / enthusiasm
  • Proof - working examples

Theory & goals

StackMates focuses on micro components based on the belief that monolithic stacks no matter how well intended eventually encourage fiefdoms of protectionism that ultimately lead to entropy. Instead micro culture is about reinventing on principle where everything is considered disposable.

  • Dont mix build logic in your domain specific code have a master build engine - minimise rework
  • Identify a solid core of standard modules by job to be done
  • Create taxonomy for standard UX patterns - like bootstrap has but based on Suit.css
  • Create a spotter network for fullstack solutions out on micro components to save time hunting around modules
  • Allow developers to create, share, analyse trends of StackMate bundles
  • Create consistent evolution path for publishing new npm modules or services
  • Teach new concepts in context of a larger ecosystem

StackMates config files

  • NPM: package.json
  • Rework: main.css or SASS: main.scss
  • Browserify: index.js
  • Gulp: config
  • Hapi: config

Docker orchestration?

  • Fig
  • nscale
  • Kubernetes

See a summary of StackMates Components

Development Flow

  • Substance - first principles inputs and desired outputs
  • Structure - how to make things flow
  • Connection - give client what they need when they need

Client: it starts up front: In rugby there is an adage that if you dont win the battle upfront you will probably lose the game. By the same token if you dont provide an engaging user experience you wont win customers data.

By starting upfront you dont lose your story and run the risk of creating results that customer dont want.

  • Seperate client and backend on principle until business case justifies it
  • Dont begin services work until you have worked out the UX story

Services: feed the backs: Again from rugby - though more controversial - you need to feed your backs to convert possesion and territory into points. This is analogous to capturing as much data as you can to turn into insights for growing profits.

  • Make decisions based on KPIs that directly impact cashflow
  • Capture everything, publish conclusions

Introduction

Continue on for an introduction to the stack and why each technology has been chosen. Or see this spreadsheet for a fast overview.

externalProvoke.communicationJob: Javascript glues the web together and node is here to stay. The business case contnues to grow for node.js as it fast becomes a core requirement of the web development process.
externalProvoke.communicationTeaching: With regards to nodejs the education market is not as comprehensive as rails by comparison, this might be due to relative age and fragmentation of solutions. It would be nice to see a leader such as nodesource follow thoughtbot's lead with rails. That said nodeschool is very good.
externalProvoke.leadership: Joyant: Probably could be improved but have Walmart snapping at their heels to keep them honest
externalProvoke.innovation: At the forefront of web innovation with a rich and rapidly evolving ecosystem with projects such as Microsoft's winjs
externalProvoke.developmentProductivity: JavaScript is the ultimate utility language and often node has been adopted by leading companies when experiments proved so productive the decision was made to go all in.
externalProvoke.developmentPerformance: Delivers responsive (realtime) user experience while in terms of infrastructure costs Node will save you money. Node.js owes much of it's speed to google's ch
externalProvoke.developmentFlexibility: This might be why developers have embraced node.js in the first place. While javascript is undergoing constant evolution as the language that glues the web together.
externalProvoke.ecosystemDevelopers: Attacts top talent and top talent is the key to growth the beautiful thing is that it is all javascript which enables a single developer to be more productive.
externalProvoke.ecosystemProof: Big brands have already realised they can use node to grow their profits
externalProvoke.ecosystemModules: Huge amount of open-source ecosystems with over 90,000 packages on NPM
externalProvoke.html:
Innovative fullstack solutions

  • Meteor - Next generation framework
  • Nodebb - Forum
  • Reactioncommerce - Realtime ecommerce
  • Apostrophenow - CMS
  • Keystonejs - CMS
  • Ghost - Blogging

Problems

  • Are enough people dedicated to the core team?
  • Still growing into mainstream
  • Evented model for development takes adjustment
  • Seen as a tool for the big boys
An investment in JavaScript provides flexibility

externalProvoke.communicationJob: Gulp runs tasks to run development environment with live browser reloading and creating production builds with performance optimisaton for your sites by minify concatenating and minifying JavaScript, CSS, HTML and images.
externalProvoke.leadership: Fractal: Do a good job setting gulp's strict plugin guidelines to assure plugins stay simple and work the way you expect. Work to prevent ecosystem is not populuted with pointless plugins.
externalProvoke.innovation: Build processes are continually improving to automate tasks that speed the web development workflow
externalProvoke.developmentProductivity: With a minimal API surface you can pick up gulp in no time. Your build works just like you envision it
externalProvoke.developmentPerformance: By harnessing the power of node's streams you get fast builds that don't write intermediary files to disk.
externalProvoke.developmentFlexibility: By preferring code over configuration, gulp keeps simple things simple and makes complex tasks manageable.
externalProvoke.ecosystemDevelopers: Strong and growing converts from Grunt.
externalProvoke.ecosystemProof: See Google's web starter kit, Fractal's own hackathon starter
externalProvoke.ecosystemModules: Over 750 curated plugins that carefully scrutinised to be of proven value and following good principles.
externalProvoke.stackmatesHistory: Maintaining the build system across multiple projects I was spending more time maintaining each build system than doing the work intended.
externalProvoke.stackmatesIntent: Cherry pick the best ideas from projects like the web starter kit and the gulp starter. Need to sort image processing solution for RWD process.
externalProvoke.excerpt: Features: The major difference is that a master build system is shared by many projects so you only have to think about keeping one build system up to date.
externalProvoke.html:
Features: The major difference is that a master build system is shared by many projects so you only have to think about keeping one build system up to date.

  • Clean build directories
  • Fetch and compress assets such as icons, fonts, json data
  • Concate and compress javascript with browserify
  • Browsersync or live-reload
  • Fetch cordova assets

The goal is to that is used by and used with a twist at medium

You can decide between SASS or Rework. Rework is my first preference because it is very fast and that is what is used by Suit.css. Howeve SASS is available to supports Ionic and there are many other projects out there to learn from.

Workflow

You should be able to read a fragment of HTML and know where the partial is what the intent of styles rules. IDs are should only be used for scrolling to anchors otherwise use data attributes for javascript. It should be possible to open the relevant CSS or JS file by typing four characters that are made clear by looking at markup.

prefix rules to add navigation

CSS

  • u : utility rules
  • t : typography
  • dt : typography rules in domain

Each domain has a shared css manifest and each sub-domain has a specific css manifest that references the common base.

Handlebars

Partials and helpers the common templates directory but screen views are copied from a reference library into the specific project.

externalProvoke.excerpt: Substack's Browserify demos are a big inspiration for this project. Browserify lets you require('modules') in the browser by bundling up all of your dependencies.
externalProvoke.html:
Substacks Browserify demos are a big inspiration for this project. Browserify lets you require(modules) in the browser by bundling up all of your dependencies.

What Browserify enables is helping developer to think small by modules that do one job but can be combined together with open possibilities

Benefits

Speed of development: There is a learning curve but once a you know the npm ecosystem then you are away.

Performance: Providing you select modules wisely you can use only the javascript you need to ensure fast page load times.

Flexibility: With knowledge of the browserify and NPM you can build anything without a framework. This apporach has advantages when very specific solutions with minimal code footprint is required.

Developer support & innovation: This could be the greatest strength, ampersand and mercury are two projects built around the idea of using browserify to build flexible solutions, while famou.us has browserify support in the pipeline.

Problems

The problem with browserify is finding the module you want and getting modules to work that are not written for NPM. Understanding how to evaluate whether to use a module.

But solving this problem is one use case that sharing StackMate bundles is intended to resolve.

Structure

Common are split into util modules and modules that support ux patterns for example site nav overlay

Workflow

Sites and Apps can be built from anything that can be browserified

Module Development: Code starts in specific projects then be extracted into StackMates Common Directory to be further researched for whether another module exists in NPM or if a new NPM module should be created. The idea of having a holding areas is to allow a bit more thought about whether a better solution for the ecosystem rather than polute NPM needlessly with new modules.

App specific => Common => Find best pattern => Research NPM => Create necessary modules in NPM

StackMates Component

  • index.js

Learn more

  • Substack - finding modules
  • Mind Map

Unknowns / Jobs

  • Good heuristics for module review and update
  • Establish heuristics for module extraction process
  • Is it a good idea to move package.json upstream for clearer demarcation of module purpose?
  • Replace bower components

Choosing angular for it-starts-upfront had more to do with the decision to use Ionic Framework and the efficiency gains for developing in mobile apps.

But Angular has become the modern jQuery with so many examples that can pretty browserified pretty quickly.

The structure of angular code is a mix of John Papas and Todd Mottos with the browserify twist. With the ambition to develop a full suite of style guide examples with tests

externalProvoke.excerpt: This google drive directory can be used to communicate knowledge and track important information.
externalProvoke.html:
This google drive directory can be used to communicate knowledge and track important information.

Intent

Part of the StackMates philosophy is delay choosing software solutions until you really know your use case. So this project starter directory can be used communicate for your projects. See dreamineering for a guide to the structure of this directory.

The benefit is that no-one needs to learn a new tool to understand how the project is evolving and using the external folder it is possible to use the drive as a simple CMS solution where stackedit.io which integrates with google+ can be used streamline your workflow and take care of loading images. Unfortunately stackedit.io is a bit slow.

Startups

If you have a startup idea check out Google Launch you will find some useful resources and receive credit on googles compute engine if your idea gets through.

Structure

The folder structure replicates our personal thoughts, there are those that are meant for the outside world external and those we would rather keep to a select few internal

Learn

Ive attempted to collect good ideas from around the web here to go with this process

externalProvoke.excerpt: The structure can be improved and this won't a solution for everyone.
externalProvoke.html:
The structure can be improved and this wont a solution for everyone.

But there is value in complexity and it seems very likely micro-service architecture has a strong future so hopefully this can become a useful resource for learning.

Progress

The solution is still very early in development but it already scratches a few itches and will only get better as more ideas get added and other become cleaner with better documentation. The apps are still largely ignored but given increasingly ubiquitous coverage of angular on dailyjs a complex solution would be easy to build up.

Future

Analysis of StackMates would make it easier to indentify what trends were developing for the purposes of deciding how to invest efforts in education.

To do this the next goal is allow developer to agree criteria and then give their evaluation rating of the major building blocks

Alternatives

It would be cool to see a completely different build engine and strategy using something like duo and graftjs for example.

Issues to tackle

  • Figure out the what?, when?, why? and how? of the realtime story
  • Enable a more productive action than staring interesting projects
  • Create flash cards of main concepts with links to code for learning with context
  • Develop non trivial micro-service architectured solutions with examples of the contrasting approaches in action
  • Identify best development to production workflow with MSA and docker
